slides.title: Introduction to Policy Changes and Preemption
slides.notes: In this lesson, you'll learn about policy changes and the concept of preemption in PolicyCenter. We'll explore how changes can affect policy details and premiums, and how preemption ensures consistency in policy versions.
slides.narration: Welcome to our exploration of policy changes and preemption in PolicyCenter. As a developer, understanding these concepts is crucial for maintaining consistency and accuracy within policy data. We'll delve into how policy changes impact premiums and the mechanics behind preemption that ensure seamless version control. Let's get started on this journey of mastering policy transactions.
slides.ocrText: Policy Changes and Preemption

slides.title: Understanding Policy Changes
slides.notes: Policy changes are transactions that involve material changes to a policy. They often result in a change to the policy's premium and are crucial for updating coverage details.
slides.narration: Policy changes, commonly referred to as transactions, are a fundamental part of PolicyCenter's functionality. These changes ensure that policy coverage details are current and accurate, often affecting the policy's premium. As developers, it's important to understand how these changes interact with the data model, particularly entities like PolicyPeriod and Coverage.
slides.ocrText:
Lesson
objectives

Perform a policy change

Change the effective date of a policy change
Interpret policy transaction graphs

Describe preemption behavior

Handle preemptions

slides.title: The Role of Effective Dates
slides.notes: Effective dates determine when a policy change takes effect. They are crucial for aligning coverage with real-world events, such as acquiring a new vehicle.
slides.narration: Effective dates play a pivotal role in policy changes. They determine when a change becomes active, aligning the policy with real-world events like purchasing a new vehicle. This is where entities like PolicyPeriod come into play, ensuring that the coverage reflects these changes accurately in the system.
slides.ocrText:
Dahlia

slides.title: Policy Change Mechanics
slides.originalNotes:
Policy Change
A change transaction is also referred to as a "policy change". A"material change" is a change to a policy that affects what is covered. Policy changes involve material changes. Policy changes frequently involve a change to the policy's premium.
slides.notes:
Policy Change
A change transaction is also referred to as a "policy change". A"material change" is a change to a policy that affects what is covered. Policy changes involve material changes. Policy changes frequently involve a change to the policy's premium.
slides.narration: Policy changes are transactions that modify the core aspects of a policy, often involving material changes that impact coverage. These changes are crucial for adapting policies to new circumstances, and they typically result in a premium adjustment. Understanding the data model, including entities like Policy and PolicyPeriod, helps us manage these changes effectively.

slides.title: Demonstration: Initiating a Policy Change
slides.originalNotes:
Demonstration
Show students a simple policy change for the line of business ( LOB) of interest Share information about effective dateswith students as well as "material changes" (covered in Policy Transactions).

Start Policy Change: You can start manually, but an external system can also initiate a change.
Progressing: After users specify an effective date and description (although not required, it is best practice to provide a change transaction description), the change wizard is displayed. From this point, users can go to any of the steps prior to the Quote and modify the policy. If you choose to edit an effectivedate, the current quote will become invalid.
 Issue Change: After binding, the change becomes a legal part of the contract as of the change's effective date.
Policy Change Review: Show the policy changes and explain how to review.
Requote: The policy must be requoted since there have been changes that may affect the premium.

From this point, users can go to any of the steps prior to the Quote and modify the policy. If you choose to edit an effectivedate, the current quote will become invalid.

slides.narration: Let's dive into a demonstration of initiating a policy change. Observe how we start the change process, either manually or through an external trigger. Pay attention to how effective dates are set, as they determine the start of new coverage. As you follow along, notice how the PolicyChange entity captures these details, and how the wizard guides you through modifying policy details before issuing the change.

slides.title: Progressing a Policy Change
slides.notes: After specifying an effective date and description, the change wizard is displayed. Users can modify the policy before quoting.
slides.narration: Once a policy change is initiated, we enter the change wizard. This interface allows users to define effective dates and provide descriptions, offering clarity on the nature of the change. The wizard is a powerful tool for navigating through various policy elements, ensuring that all necessary modifications are captured before moving to the quoting phase.

slides.title: Editing Effective Dates
slides.originalNotes:
Edit the effective date of an unbound policy change
Frequently, a customer wants to make a policy change. All theinitial data for the change gets captured, but then the effective date of the policy change must be modified before the policy change is issued. A common use case is changing the date when a coverage starts for a newly acquired vehicle:
A customer is buying a new vehicle and calls the insurance company to determine how much coverage for the new vehicle will cost. A policy change is started but not issued.
They expect to receive the vehicle on a certain date (e.g. October 1 on the slide), so the policy change is effective for that date. However, the vehicle is delayed and is not received until the following month (November 1).
The agent changes the effective date of the already in progress change to November 1 ( 11/01).
However, if the initial policy change has been issued, youmust start a new policy change using the new effective date.
slides.notes:
Edit the effective date of an unbound policy change
Frequently, a customer wants to make a policy change. All theinitial data for the change gets captured, but then the effective date of the policy change must be modified before the policy change is issued. A common use case is changing the date when a coverage starts for a newly acquired vehicle:
A customer is buying a new vehicle and calls the insurance company to determine how much coverage for the new vehicle will cost. A policy change is started but not issued.
They expect to receive the vehicle on a certain date (e.g. October 1 on the slide), so the policy change is effective for that date. However, the vehicle is delayed and is not received until the following month (November 1).
The agent changes the effective date of the already in progress change to November 1 ( 11/01).
However, if the initial policy change has been issued, youmust start a new policy change using the new effective date.
slides.narration: A common scenario in policy changes is adjusting the effective date of an unbound change. For instance, when a customer expects to receive a new vehicle on a specific date, but delays occur, the effective date must be updated. This flexibility is crucial for ensuring that policies accurately reflect current circumstances, and it's facilitated by entities like PolicyPeriod and PolicyChange.

slides.title: Handling Delays in Policy Changes
slides.notes: Adjustments to effective dates are common in policy changes, especially when real-world events are delayed.
slides.narration: Handling delays in policy changes requires a keen understanding of how effective dates interact with policy data. As developers, we must ensure that the system allows for seamless updates to these dates, maintaining data integrity and ensuring that policies remain aligned with actual events. This often involves interacting with entities like PolicyChange and Coverage.

slides.title: Reviewing Policy Changes
slides.notes: Reviewing changes before issuing them ensures accuracy and compliance with policyholder expectations.
slides.narration: Before issuing a policy change, a thorough review is essential. This step ensures that all modifications are accurate and meet the policyholder's expectations. The review process is integral to maintaining data integrity and compliance, leveraging the PolicyChange entity to capture and verify every detail before finalization.

slides.originalNotes:
Simple scenarios
The boxes are the policy periods created by the policy
transactions, not the transactions themselves.
slides.notes:
Simple scenarios
The boxes are the policy periods created by the policy
transactions, not the transactions themselves.
slides.narration: Understanding the relationship between policy transactions and policy periods is crucial. Each transaction results in a new policy period, which reflects the updated coverage and terms. This distinction is important for developers, as it affects how we manage and query policy data within the system.

slides.title: Complex Policy Change Scenarios
slides.notes: Exploring more complex scenarios helps developers anticipate challenges in policy changes.
slides.narration: As we move into more complex scenarios, consider how multiple transactions can interact within PolicyCenter. Understanding these interactions helps us anticipate challenges and design solutions that maintain data consistency and accuracy across policy versions.

Most policy transactions modify a copy of an existing PolicyPeriod

* This period is known as the "base period" for that transaction

slides.title: What Leads to Preemptions?
slides.originalNotes:
What may lead to Preemptions?
In the example, the submission creates a personal auto policy with car 1. A change transaction adds a second car to the policy. However, before the transaction is bound, a second change is started which adds a truck to the policy. The "truck" change job must be based on the latest bound version, because the "car 2" change job is not completed. The latest bound version is version A, the same version that the "car 2" job was based on.
slides.notes:
What may lead to Preemptions?
In the example, the submission creates a personal auto policy with car 1. A change transaction adds a second car to the policy. However, before the transaction is bound, a second change is started which adds a truck to the policy. The "truck" change job must be based on the latest bound version, because the "car 2" change job is not completed. The latest bound version is version A, the same version that the "car 2" job was based on.
slides.narration: Preemption occurs when a new change job is initiated before a previous one is completed. For example, if a policy change adds a car but another change adds a truck, the truck change must be based on the latest bound version of the policy. This ensures that all changes are consistent and based on the most up-to-date information.

Preemption is a phenomenon which occurs when two transactions have been
initiated from the same base period

* This occurs when a new transaction is started while another transaction is still in progress

slides.title: Preempting Jobs in PolicyCenter
slides.originalNotes:
Preempting job
Remember that transactions and jobs are used interchangeably in PolicyCenter.
slides.notes:
Preempting job
Remember that transactions and jobs are used interchangeably in PolicyCenter.
slides.narration: In PolicyCenter, the terms 'transactions' and 'jobs' are often used interchangeably, especially when discussing preemption. Preempting involves starting a new job that affects the same policy elements as an ongoing one, requiring careful management to ensure consistency and avoid conflicts in policy data.
slides.ocrText:
| Preempting job fa

into effect or expires

Submission
Change

Preempted ie >|
change

When two or more jobs are started from same base period, the first job to be bound
preempts (wins out over) all other jobs

* Losing jobs must be modified to handle preemption

slides.title: Managing Preemptions
slides.notes: Managing preemptions requires a deep understanding of policy data and transaction states.
slides.narration: Managing preemptions effectively is a key skill for developers working with PolicyCenter. It involves understanding the current state of policy transactions and ensuring that any new changes are compatible with existing data. This often requires interaction with entities like PolicyPeriod and ChangeJob to maintain data integrity.

slides.title: Preemption Warnings
slides.notes: Warnings alert users to potential preemptions before changes are made.
slides.narration: PolicyCenter provides warnings when a potential preemption might occur, alerting users to review existing changes before proceeding. These warnings are crucial for maintaining the integrity of policy data, ensuring that all changes are intentional and well-managed.

slides.title: Preemption Warning for Policy Changes
slides.originalNotes:
Preemption warning: Policy change
When you initiate a change and another change is in progress, you are warned before the change wizard is initiated.
slides.notes:
Preemption warning: Policy change
When you initiate a change and another change is in progress, you are warned before the change wizard is initiated.
slides.narration: When initiating a new policy change, if another change is already in progress, PolicyCenter will issue a warning before allowing the new change to proceed. This feature is crucial for developers to understand, as it helps prevent data conflicts and ensures that policy updates are handled in a controlled and consistent manner.

slides.narration: When a change job preempts other transactions, PolicyCenter provides a helpful feature on the Policy Change Bound screen, displaying links to the preempted transactions. This allows users to easily navigate and review the affected jobs, ensuring that all changes are properly tracked and managed.

slides.title: Handling Preempted Transactions
slides.originalNotes:
Preempted transaction
When a change job is preempted, the user is alerted when trying to complete the preempted job.
slides.notes:
Preempted transaction
When a change job is preempted, the user is alerted when trying to complete the preempted job.
slides.narration: In the event of a preempted transaction, users are alerted when attempting to complete the affected job. This alert is crucial for maintaining control over policy data, ensuring that all changes are reviewed and reconciled before finalization. It emphasizes the importance of understanding transaction states and their impact on policy management.

slides.title: Comparing Preempted Changes
slides.originalNotes:
Handling preemptions
The comparisons are shown in a tree format for the preemptedchanges. The "Decide Later"button makes no changes to the policy or the preempte transaction. It closes the screen. In the slide, the differences are shown in a tree format comparing the current Policy Change and the Policy Change that was bound earlier.
slides.notes:
Handling preemptions
The comparisons are shown in a tree format for the preemptedchanges. The "Decide Later"button makes no changes to the policy or the preempte transaction. It closes the screen. In the slide, the differences are shown in a tree format comparing the current Policy Change and the Policy Change that was bound earlier.
slides.narration: PolicyCenter provides a comparison view for preempted changes, displayed in a tree format. This visualization helps users understand the differences between current and previous policy states. The 'Decide Later' button is a useful feature, allowing developers to close the screen without making immediate changes, providing time to assess and plan the next steps carefully.

slides.title: Resolving Preemptions
slides.notes: Effectively resolving preemptions maintains data consistency and policy accuracy.
slides.narration: Resolving preemptions is a critical task for developers, as it ensures that policy data remains consistent and accurate. This process involves reviewing all affected transactions and making necessary adjustments to align with the latest policy state. Mastery of this skill is essential for effective policy management in PolicyCenter.

slides.title: Best Practices for Policy Changes
slides.notes: Adhering to best practices ensures smooth policy change processes and minimizes errors.
slides.narration: Adopting best practices when handling policy changes can significantly reduce errors and streamline the process. These practices include thorough reviews of all changes, careful management of effective dates, and proactive handling of preemptions to maintain data integrity and policy accuracy.

slides.title: Review and Requote Process
slides.notes: The review and requote process ensures that any changes affecting premiums are accurately reflected.
slides.narration: The review and requote process is an essential step in policy changes, particularly when modifications impact premiums. This ensures that all changes are accurately reflected in the policy data and that the premium calculations remain correct. As developers, understanding how to effectively manage this process is crucial for maintaining policy integrity.

slides.title: Summary and Next Steps: Renewals
slides.notes: Summarize key points about policy changes and preemption. Preview the next lesson on renewals.
slides.narration: In this lesson, we've covered the intricacies of policy changes and the concept of preemption within PolicyCenter. Mastering these concepts ensures accurate policy management and data integrity. As we move forward, our next lesson will focus on renewals, where we'll explore how to manage the renewal process effectively. Stay tuned for more insights into optimizing policy lifecycles.
